instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.PPVCC_S0_CPU: What is PPVCC_S0_CPU? The "PPVCC_S0_CPU" power rail is responsible for supplying power to the CPU when the MacBook is fully on, or in the S0 state. This rail is one of the main voltages that the CPU requires for operation. .
definitions.PP1V05_S0:
What is PP1V05_S0? The PP1V05_S0 power rail is for various components on the logic board that require a 1.05V supply voltage in the S0 (on) state. This voltage rail is likely to be used by the CPU (for VCCIO), PCH (Platform Controller Hub).

.

threads.title: 00165 Full Fan No Boot (Cold CPU)
threads.message:
Have a 00165 that goes to full fan immediately upon plug-in (regardless of TP). Checked all rails are present except no VCORE. Noted some solder balls around <CAPACITOR>C1031</CAPACITOR>, but other than that the board looks absolutely fine. All 3.3 V present, all 5V present, all 1.8V present (except VCORE), all 1.2V Present.
Thoughts?

threads.title: 00165 Full Fan No Boot (Cold CPU)
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> level?
Do you get something at pins 7 & 3 of <CHIP>U1950</CHIP>?

threads.title: 00165 Full Fan No Boot (Cold CPU)
threads.message:
Nothing on <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>
Nothing on P7  and P3 <CHIP>U1950</CHIP>

threads.title: 00165 Full Fan No Boot (Cold CPU)
threads.message:
One power supply involved on <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> generation fails.
Can also be corrosion at <CHIP>U1950</CHIP>, or <TRANSISTOR>Q8150</TRANSISTOR>.
Check that area...

threads.title: 00165 Full Fan No Boot (Cold CPU)
threads.message: What do you mean by that first sentence?

threads.title: 00165 Full Fan No Boot (Cold CPU)
threads.message: A bad power supply can pulls down <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>...

threads.title: 00165 Full Fan No Boot (Cold CPU)
threads.message: Ahh. Ok. What would be an example of this?

threads.title: 00165 Full Fan No Boot (Cold CPU)
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> is generated on page 59.
A bunch of resistors bring power good signals from several power supplies.
You can remove one by one, untill <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> goes high.
The last removed denotes the failing power supply.
You can start removing <TRANSISTOR>Q8150</TRANSISTOR>, which is not even necessary.
Be aware, do NOT remove <RESISTOR>R8167</RESISTOR>; is the pull-up resistor for <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> signal.

threads.title: 00165 Full Fan No Boot (Cold CPU)
threads.message: Excellent, I will check this out and report back

threads.title: 00165 Full Fan No Boot (Cold CPU)
threads.message:
So I read <RESISTOR>R8162</RESISTOR>, 64, 65, 66, <RESISTOR>R1962</RESISTOR>-All within range
There is no <RESISTOR>R8167</RESISTOR> on this board
Thoughts?

threads.title: 00165 Full Fan No Boot (Cold CPU)
threads.message:
MLB will not work without that resistor, solder it.
And I told you to remove mentioned resistors one by one, not to check their values.
However, your issue should be missing <RESISTOR>R8167</RESISTOR>, do not tocuh anything else.

threads.title: 00165 Full Fan No Boot (Cold CPU)
threads.message: I will attempt, however, it looks as if its a nostuff. it looks factory, not knocked off or removed.

threads.title: 00165 Full Fan No Boot (Cold CPU)
threads.message: Sorry, I must've had a long day that day. <RESISTOR>R8162</RESISTOR> is no stuff... Not 8167, 8167 is indeed there. I removed <RESISTOR>R8168</RESISTOR>, <RESISTOR>R8164</RESISTOR>, <RESISTOR>R8165</RESISTOR>, and <RESISTOR>R8166</RESISTOR>, one by one and <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> Did not change.

threads.title: 00165 Full Fan No Boot (Cold CPU)
threads.message:
Do you have 3V at pin 1/<RESISTOR>R8167</RESISTOR>?
Did you remove <TRANSISTOR>Q8150</TRANSISTOR>?

threads.title: 00165 Full Fan No Boot (Cold CPU)
threads.message: Removed <TRANSISTOR>Q1850</TRANSISTOR>, <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> reading 3.3v now. Still no power to CPU. No <SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0</SIGNAL>. 1.7V at <SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: 00165 Full Fan No Boot (Cold CPU)
threads.message:
"No <SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0</SIGNAL>"
Check <CHIP>U7600</CHIP>/<TRANSISTOR>Q7630</TRANSISTOR> power supply.

"Still no power to CPU
--------------------------
1.7V at <SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL>"
Are you sure???
